docs.lead_paragraph: If the U.S. Supreme Court blows up the tax subsidies at the heart of Obamacare in June, Republicans hope to deliver on their promise to offer an alternative healthcare plan.

headline.main: Seeking Obamacare Alternative, Republicans Eye Tax Credits
headline.print_headline: Seeking Obamacare Alternative, Republicans Eye Tax Credits

docs.snippet: If the U.S. Supreme Court blows up the tax subsidies at the heart of Obamacare in June, Republicans hope to deliver on their promise to offer an alternative healthcare plan.

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of American executives visited Iran and looked for opportunities if sanctions are eventually lifted.

headline.main: Billboards in Iran Say ‘Death to America,’ but Officials Say ‘Let’s Make a Deal’
headline.print_headline: Billboards Say ‘Death to America,’ but Officials Say ‘Let’s Make a Deal’

docs.abstract: Tehran Journal; visit by group of American business executives to Iran's capital Tehran, organized by Young Presidents' Org, indicates interest American business community has about making inroads in Iran; country has long been off-limits because of sanctions, but negotiators working on Iran's nuclear program seem confident that sanctions will be eased.
docs.snippet: A group of American executives visited Iran and looked for opportunities if sanctions are eventually lifted.

docs.lead_paragraph: The retail tycoon, who turned Sotheby’s into a global power for art sales, went to prison in a price-fixing scandal involving Christie’s that, prosecutors said, cheated buyers and sellers out of $100 million.

headline.main: A. Alfred Taubman, 91, Dies; Developer, Sotheby’s Owner and Focus of Scandal
headline.print_headline: A. Alfred Taubman, Former Sotheby’s Owner and Mall Developer, Dies at 91

docs.abstract: A Alfred Taubman, an art collector and shopping-mall tycoon who turned Sotheby's auction house into a global power of art sales, dies at age 91.
docs.snippet: The retail tycoon, who turned Sotheby’s into a global power for art sales, went to prison in a price-fixing scandal involving Christie’s that, prosecutors said, cheated buyers and sellers out of $100 million.

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican or Democrat, the next president will have the chance to remake the nation's health care overhaul without fighting Congress.

headline.main: For Next President, a Way Out of the Health Care Fights?
headline.print_headline: For Next President, a Way Out of the Health Care Fights?

docs.snippet: Republican or Democrat, the next president will have the chance to remake the nation's health care overhaul without fighting Congress.

docs.lead_paragraph: Communities puzzle over when to regulate odors.

headline.main: Would You Want to Smell BBQ All the Time?
headline.print_headline: Would You Want to Smell BBQ All the Time?

docs.abstract: News Analysis; city council meeting in Austin, Tex, focused on proposal to control barbecue odor in response to citizen complaints, highlights problem local governments around country have with regulating smells; issue is complicated by fact that reactions to odors are entirely subjective.
docs.snippet: Communities puzzle over when to regulate odors.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Farragut Houses, a city housing project in northwest Brooklyn, suffer from economic and physical isolation.

headline.main: Promised a Supermarket Five Years Ago, a Housing Project Is Still Waiting

docs.abstract: Residents of Farragut Houses, city housing project in northwest Brooklyn, have few nearby options for affordable fresh food; 3,500 tenants will have to wait until at least late 2017 for a close proposed supermarket to open, despite announcement from Bloomberg administration in 2010 that a redevelopment plan was underway, with a supermarket a key feature of the proposal.
docs.snippet: The Farragut Houses, a city housing project in northwest Brooklyn, suffer from economic and physical isolation.

docs.lead_paragraph: Children’s credit records are clean, and they don’t check their credit reports, two conditions data thieves take advantage of.

headline.main: Identity Theft Poses Extra Troubles for Children
headline.print_headline: Identity Theft Poses Extra Risk for Children

docs.abstract: Ron Lieber Your Money column observes that children are particularly attractive targets for identity theft because their credit reports are clean; notes difficulty for parents in shielding children from possible identity theft given that most do not have credit history.
docs.snippet: Children’s credit records are clean, and they don’t check their credit reports, two conditions data thieves take advantage of.

docs.lead_paragraph: Cardinal Francis George, a vigorous defender of Roman Catholic orthodoxy who played a key role in the church's response to the clergy sex abuse scandal and led the U.S. bishops' fight against Obamacare, has died after a long fight with cancer. He was 78.

headline.main: Cardinal Francis George, Key Catholic Orthodoxy Voice, Dies
headline.print_headline: Cardinal Francis George, Key Catholic Orthodoxy Voice, Dies

headline.main: Ask Well: Do I Need an Annual Physical?
headline.print_headline: Ask Well: Are Yearly Physicals Really Necessary?

docs.abstract: An annual physical is routine for about 45 million Americans. Should it be?
docs.snippet: An annual physical is routine for about 45 million Americans. Should it be?

docs.lead_paragraph: Saul Webster enjoys a good tipple, and nobody begrudges him one. But that doesn't make it good politics for the retired schoolteacher to pose for a campaign event with Nigel Farage, the U.K. Independence Party leader, while carrying a bottle of hard cider and a half-drained glass.
